App description:
Create smooth, polygonal, and cubey sculptures and worlds of any size. SculptrVR's 10,000x zoom enables massive creations with tiny details! SculptrVR gives you almost unlimited space so your imagination is totally free!

SculptrVRs intuitive and fun tools let your imagination turn into real creations.

Get a better view of your sculpted landscapes by Hang gliding through them.

Join an online game with 4 friends (cross platform with Go and Rift!) to build massive monuments together or have a sculpt-off!

When you're happy with your creation, you can upload to the SculptrVR content gallery and let others see the incredible things you've made. You can also browse the gallery with hundreds of creations!

Creations made in SculptrVR can be exported to OBJ or FBX formats for 3D printing or sharing online!

In your world, anything is possible.

Best asset app!

I'd recommend this app to anyone who wants to rapidly make assets for a game. Unlike a lot of other apps you can just form the general shape procedurally and go back and smoothen it out and then quickly zoom rotate and sculpt out the details. The Export option is a major and powerful because, from there you can export an .obj or .fbx and open up what are generally primary 3D programs to just basically touch them up or leave as is and skip the other programs entirely. It's like using a scanner without the hassle of photogrammetry or expensive scanning equipment to make instantly game ready asset. Game Changer!

Jadranko.K-KApr 22 at 10:09 PM
The magic of sculpting in VR

This app is simple and powerful. Simple because it boots almost instantaneously with no nonsensical intros and just drops you in a virtual environment ready to start creating stuff. The tools are intuitive and easy to learn, some may miss a tutorial but I'd rather simply watch a YouTube video. You can sculpt pretty impressive 3D models. As with any other art/craft it takes some time to master. I was very proud of the first model I created on day 1 but it is taking me some time to get to the level that I want. Exporting models to the computer or importing reference images is possible and easy but you need to connect to your computer with the USB cable, which I find a bit tedious (this is a general complaint about Oculus Quest, though). Check the online creations by other people, some are childish and basic but some are incredibly good. The multiplayer mode is a plus: join a random gane with strangers and enjoy sculpting some nonsense.

MetaverseCatDec 23 at 4:27 PM
Sculpting in VR is Wonderful

SculptrVR feels pretty crude at first, but after some practice you start to understand the hidden power of what at first feels like a big: dynamic voxel density.

Shapes seem muddy and ugly at first, but refining them into real models is a simple matter of running finer tools over the model, and with practice this becomes a natural first step to making something.

The interface is simplified perhaps a bit too far, and some tools like undo being right there under your non-dominant thumb aren't obvious at first.

All of which to say first impressions can be deceiving, and SculptrVR is a tool that started at the bottom of my list for 3D, but is now on top!

Very different than tilt brush. GET BOTH

Absolutely amazing.
I only purchased because I just got a 3D printer and thought it might be handy having a VR app around where you can export the 3D models to the printer.
I already had tilt brush so I wasnt really expecting anything much different, content/gameplay wise. But wow, I was wrong.

SculptVR actually held me for a lot longer than tilt brush did.
I believe they both have earned their place in my limited 64gb library.
Tilt brush definitely seems more paint inspired, where as sculpt is well, like the title says, sculpting.
As someone who isnt into painting or sculpting, I thought theyd be quite similar, but quite the opposite.

I love all the different tools and shapes. I love how intuitive the UI is. I love being able to adjust the sunlight.
I was impressed with myself for being able to sculpt a castle that actually kinda looked like a castle, in my first attempt. And even more besotted when I managed to give my originally dusty grey and gloomy castle a fresh white coat of paint, which inspired me to turn it into a castle birthday cake instead.
The way the brushes work really added a layer of realism I wasnt expecting.
I do wish we could have a reference photo on the screen, as oculus doesnt allow you to open the browser without closing the app.

Itd also be great if we could access a gallery of other players artwork.
But even how it is right now, its a 5 star app.
Those things would be an added bonus.
The price is an absolute steal.

JonnyCleanSep 8, 2019 at 7:15 PM
This was my quickest app purchase so far

And for the most part its quite good. It offers some tools that Tilt Brush is missing (smoothing,additive/subtractive sculpting) and it improves on the zoom/scale which is really nice. The only real gripe I have is that objects can easily loose clarity in unexpected ways. As an artist, once I have lines in place and looking just the way I want, I expect them to stay just where I put them. Instead, I found that painted surfaces lost quality as I moved around the piece and worked on other elements. So, while I love some of the tools, like the smoothing brush, I cant imagine putting a lot of time into any serious, detailed piece knowing that parts might get arbitrarily blurred away or removed as I continue to work. That said, for casual sketching and painting (which is really the focus here), its a lot of fun, and I look forward to trying multi-player.

If paint strokes could be preserved just as they are painted and a method for quickly selecting and duplicating strokes could be added, (the stamp tool is awkward and copies do not have the original resolution) This would be 5 star for sure.
